025package squidpony.squidmath;
026
027import squidpony.StringKit;
028
029import java.io.Serializable;
030
031/**
032 * This is a RandomnessSource in the PCG-Random family. It performs pseudo-
033 * random modifications to the output based on the techniques from the
034 * Permuted Congruential Generators created by M.E. O'Neill.
035 * Specifically, this variant is:
036 * RXS M XS -- random xorshift, mcg multiply, fixed xorshift
037 *
038 * The most statistically powerful generator, but all those steps
039 * make it slower than some of the others.
040 * <br>
041 * Even though benchmarks on similar programs in C would lead you to
042 * believe this should be somewhat faster than LightRNG, benchmarking
043 * with JMH seems to show LightRNG being roughly 16% faster than
044 * PermutedRNG, and both drastically faster than java.util.Random .
045 * This generator was implemented incorrectly for a large part of its history,
046 * but it seems correct now, though it may be a little slower.
047 * @author Melissa E. O'Neill (Go HMC!)
048 * @author Tommy Ettinger
049 * @see PintRNG PintRNG is similar to this algorithm but uses only 32-bit math, where possible.
050 */
051public final class PermutedRNG implements RandomnessSource, StatefulRandomness, SkippingRandomness, Serializable
052{
053        /** 2 raised to the 53, - 1. */
054    private static final long DOUBLE_MASK = ( 1L << 53 ) - 1;
055    /** 2 raised to the -53. */
056    private static final double NORM_53 = 1. / ( 1L << 53 );
057    /** 2 raised to the 24, -1. */
058    private static final long FLOAT_MASK = ( 1L << 24 ) - 1;
059    /** 2 raised to the -24. */
060    private static final double NORM_24 = 1. / ( 1L << 24 );
061    /**
062     * The state can be seeded with any value.
063     */
064    public long state;
065
066        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3748443966125527657L;
067
068    /**
069     * Creates a new generator seeded using Math.random.
070     */
071    public PermutedRNG() {
072        this((long) ((Math.random() - 0.5) * 0x10000000000000L)
073                ^ (long) (((Math.random() - 0.5) * 2.0) * 0x8000000000000000L));
074    }
075
076    /**
077     * Constructs a new PermutedRNG with the given seed as its state, exactly.
078     * @param seed a long that will be used as-is for the state of a new PermutedRNG
079     */
080    public PermutedRNG(final long seed) {
081        state = seed;
082    }
083
084    /**
085     * Gets a random int with at most the specified number of bits.
086     * Equivalent in its effect on the state to calling {@link #nextLong()} exactly one time.
087     * @param bits the number of bits to be returned, between 1 and 32
088     * @return a pseudo-random int with at most the specified bits
089     */
090    @Override
091    public final int next( final int bits ) {
092        long p = (state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL);
093        p = (p ^ p >>> (5 + (p >>> 59))) * 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L;
094        return (int)(p ^ p >>> 43) >>> (32 - bits);
095    }
096
097    /**
098     * Can return any int, positive or negative, of any size permissible in a 32-bit signed integer.
099     * Equivalent in its effect on the state to calling {@link #nextLong()} exactly one time.
100     * @return any int, all 32 bits are random
101     */
102    public int nextInt() {
103        long p = (state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL);
104        p = (p ^ p >>> (5 + (p >>> 59))) * 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L;
105        return (int)(p ^ p >>> 43);
106    }
107    /**
108     * Can return any long, positive or negative, of any size permissible in a 64-bit signed integer.
109     *
110     * @return any long, all 64 bits are random
111     */
112    @Override
113    public final long nextLong()
114    {
115        // increment  = 1442695040888963407L;
116        // multiplier = 6364136223846793005L;
117
118        long p = (state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL);
119        p = (p ^ p >>> (5 + (p >>> 59))) * 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L;
120        return (p ^ p >>> 43);
121    }
122
123    /**
124     * Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the
125     * copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just needs to
126     * copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
127     *
128     * @return a copy of this RandomnessSource
129     */
130    @Override
131    public PermutedRNG copy() {
132        return new PermutedRNG(state);
133    }
134
135    /**
136     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0.
137     * Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
138     * The bound should not be negative; use {@link IRNG#nextSignedInt(int)} if you need a negative outer bound.
139     * @param bound the upper bound; should be positive
140     * @return a random int less than n and at least equal to 0
141     */
142    public int nextInt( final int bound ) {
143        return (int)((bound * (nextLong() & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
144    }
145
146    /**
147     * Inclusive lower, exclusive upper. The upper bound is really the outer bound, and the lower bound the inner bound,
148     * because upper is permitted to be less than lower, though upper is still exclusive there.
149     * Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
150     * @param lower the lower bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
151     * @param upper the upper bound, exclusive, can be positive or negative
152     * @return a random int at least equal to lower and less than upper (if upper is less than lower, then the result
153     *         will be less than or equal to lower and greater than upper)
154     */
155    public int nextInt( final int lower, final int upper ) {
156        return lower + nextInt(upper - lower);
157    }
158
159    /**
160     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0. The bound may be negative, which will produce a non-positive
161     * result. Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
162     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be positive or negative
163     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
164     */
165    public long nextLong(long bound) {
166        long rand = nextLong();
167        final long randLow = rand & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
168        final long boundLow = bound & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
169        rand >>>= 32;
170        bound >>= 32;
171        final long t = rand * boundLow + (randLow * boundLow >>> 32);
172        return rand * bound + (t >> 32) + (randLow * bound + (t & 0xFFFFFFFFL) >> 32);
173    }
174    /**
175     * Inclusive inner, exclusive outer; both inner and outer can be positive or negative. Calls {@link #nextLong()}
176     * exactly once.
177     * @param inner the inner bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
178     * @param outer the outer bound, exclusive, can be positive or negative and may be greater than or less than inner
179     * @return a random long that may be equal to inner and will otherwise be between inner and outer
180     */
181    public long nextLong(final long inner, final long outer) {
182        return inner + nextLong(outer - inner);
183    }
184    /**
185     * Gets a uniform random double in the range {@code [0.0,1.0)}.
186     * Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
187     * @return a random double at least equal to 0.0 and less than 1.0
188     */
189    public double nextDouble() {
190        return ( nextLong() & DOUBLE_MASK ) * NORM_53;
191    }
192
193    /**
194     * Gets a uniform random double in the range [0.0,outer) given a positive parameter outer. If outer
195     * is negative, it will be the (exclusive) lower bound and 0.0 will be the (inclusive) upper bound.
196     * Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
197     *  @param outer the exclusive outer bound, can be negative
198     * @return a random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (exclusive)
199     */
200    public double nextDouble(final double outer) {
201        return nextDouble() * outer;
202    }
203
204    /**
205     * Gets a uniform random float in the range {@code [0.0,1.0)}
206     * Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
207     *
208     * @return a random float at least equal to 0.0f and less than 1.0f
209     */
210    public float nextFloat() {
211        return (float)( ( nextLong() & FLOAT_MASK ) * NORM_24 );
212    }
213
214    /**
215     * Gets a random value, true or false.
216     * Calls {@link #nextLong()} exactly once.
217     * @return a random true or false value.
218     */
219    public boolean nextBoolean() {
220        return nextLong() < 0L;
221    }
222
223    /**
224     * Given a byte array as a parameter, this will fill the array with random bytes (modifying it
225     * in-place). Calls {@link #nextLong()} {@code Math.ceil(bytes.length / 8.0)} times.
226     * @param bytes a byte array that will have its contents overwritten with random bytes.
227     */
228    public void nextBytes( final byte[] bytes ) {
229        int i = bytes.length, n;
230        while( i != 0 ) {
231            n = Math.min(i, 8 );
232            for ( long bits = nextLong(); n-- != 0; bits >>>= 8 ) bytes[ --i ] = (byte)bits;
233        }
234    }
235
236
237    /**
238     * Sets the seed of this generator (which is also the current state).
239     * @param seed the seed to use for this PermutedRNG, as if it was constructed with this seed.
240     */
241    public void setSeed( final long seed ) {
242        state = seed;
243    }
244    /**
245     * Sets the seed (also the current state) of this generator.
246     * @param seed the seed to use for this PermutedRNG, as if it was constructed with this seed.
247     */
248    @Override
249        public void setState( final long seed ) {
250        state = seed;
251    }
252    /**
253     * Gets the current state of this generator.
254     * @return the current seed of this PermutedRNG, changed once per call to {@link #nextLong()}
255     */
256    @Override
257        public long getState( ) {
258        return state;
259    }
260
261    /**
262     * Advances or rolls back the PermutedRNG's state without actually generating each number. Skips forward
263     * or backward a number of steps specified by advance, where a step is equal to one call to {@link #nextLong()},
264     * and returns the random number produced at that step (you can get the state with {@link #getState()}).
265     * Skipping ahead or behind takes more than constant time, unlike with {@link LightRNG}, but less time
266     * than calling {@link #nextLong()} {@code advance} times. Skipping backwards by one step is the worst case for this
267     * technique.
268     * @param advance Number of future generations to skip past. Can be negative to backtrack.
269     * @return the number that would be generated after generating advance random numbers.
270     */
271    @Override
272    public long skip(long advance)
273    {
274        // The method used here is based on Brown, "Random Number Generation
275        // with Arbitrary Stride,", Transactions of the American Nuclear
276        // Society (Nov. 1994).  The algorithm is very similar to fast
277        // exponentiation.
278        //
279        // Even though advance is a signed long, it is treated as unsigned, effectively, for the purposes
280        // of how many iterations it goes through (at most 63 for forwards, 64 for "backwards").
281        long acc_mult = 1, acc_plus = 0, cur_mult = 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL, cur_plus = 0x14057B7EF767814FL;
282
283        while (advance > 0L) {
284            if ((advance & 1L) != 0L) {
285                acc_mult *= cur_mult;
286                acc_plus = acc_plus*cur_mult + cur_plus;
287            }
288            cur_plus *= (cur_mult+1L);
289            cur_mult *= cur_mult;
290            advance >>>= 1;
291        }
292        long p = (state = acc_mult * state + acc_plus);
293        p = (p ^ p >>> (5 + (p >>> 59))) * 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L;
294        return (p ^ p >>> 43);
295    }
296
297    @Override
298    public String toString() {
299        return "PermutedRNG with state 0x" + StringKit.hex(state) + 'L';
300    }
301
302    /**
303     * Given suitably-different inputs as {@code state}, this will permute that state to get a seemingly-unrelated
304     * number. Unlike {@link LightRNG#determine(long)}, this will not work with inputs that are sequential, and it is
305     * recommended that subsequent calls change state with a linear congruential generator like
306     * {@code PermutedRNG.determine(state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL)}. It will be correct for
307     * any inputs, but if {@code state} is 0, then this will return 0.
308     * @param state a long that should be changed with {@code state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL}
309     * @return a pseudo-random long determined from state
310     */
311    public static long determine(long state)
312    {
313        state = (state ^ state >>> (5 + (state >>> 59))) * 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L;
314        return (state >>> 43) ^ state;
315    }
316
317    /**
318     * Given suitably-different inputs as {@code state}, this will permute that state to get a seemingly-unrelated
319     * number as an int between 0 and bound. Unlike {@link LightRNG#determine(long)}, this will not work with inputs
320     * that are sequential, and it is recommended that subsequent calls change state with a linear congruential
321     * generator like {@code PermutedRNG.determine(state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL)}. It will
322     * be correct for any inputs, but if {@code state} is 0, then this will return 0.
323     * @param state a long that should be changed with {@code state = state * 0x5851F42D4C957F2DL + 0x14057B7EF767814FL}
324     * @param bound the exclusive outer bound on the numbers this can produce, as an int
325     * @return a pseudo-random int between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive) determined from state
326     */
327    public static int determineBounded(long state, int bound)
328    {
329        state ^= state >>> (5 + (state >>> 59));
330        return (bound = (int)((bound * ((((state *= 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L) >>> 43) ^ state) & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31)) + (bound >>> 31);
331    }
332}
